title: 107_hr370
content: The "Education Improvement Tax Cut Act" allows for a credit for contributions to charitable organizations providing elementary or secondary school scholarships under section 25B of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Education Improvement Tax Cut Act" allows individuals to receive a tax credit for qualified scholarship contributions up to $3,000 ($1,500 for married individuals filing separately). Qualified scholarship contributions are defined as cash donations to school tuition organizations. The term 'school tuition organization' refers to an organization that primarily disburses scholarships for elementary and secondary school education. No deduction is allowed for contributions if a credit is claimed. There is an option to elect not to apply the credit. Taxpayers can elect not to apply a specific section for a taxable year and have a 3-year period to make or revoke this election. Dollar amounts in subsection (b) are adjusted for inflation for taxable years after 2002. The section discusses adjustments for inflation in tax credits, with specific provisions for married individuals filing separately. The Secretary is required to prescribe regulations for claiming the credit on Form 1040EZ. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections for subpart A of the tax code. Section 25C allows for tax credits for contributions of instructional materials and materials for extracurricular activities. Effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2001. Tax credits are allowed for qualified school materials contributions made by individuals. The maximum credit is $3,000 ($1,500 for married individuals filing separately). Qualified school materials contribution refers to cash donations to elementary or secondary schools designated for specific purposes. Tax credits are allowed for qualified school materials contributions made by individuals to elementary or secondary schools. Contributions can be designated for specific purposes such as acquiring school materials or cash donations to school materials organizations. Elementary or secondary school refers to organizations providing education up to the 12th grade. A school materials organization is defined as an organization primarily raising funds for elementary schools. The organization's purpose is to raise funds for elementary or secondary schools, with annual disbursements for qualified school materials not less than 90% of their annual income. Qualified school materials include instructional materials, equipment, and materials for schools. The organization raises funds for schools, with disbursements for school materials and equipment for extracurricular activities. No double benefit deduction is allowed for contributions eligible for a credit. Taxpayers can elect to not apply this section for any taxable year. Beginning in a calendar year after 2002, dollar amounts in subsection (b) will be increased annually based on the cost-of-living adjustment. Any increase not a multiple of $10 will be rounded up. For married individuals filing separately, the adjustment is $5 instead of $10. The Secretary will create regulations for claiming the credit on Form 1040EZ. The credit under this section on Form 1040EZ is amended by inserting a new item after section 25B in the table of sections. Effective Date: The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2001.
